lcInstruction.p: Bookmaps extend the functionality of maps by providing elements that allow you to create book-like structures, such as chapters, frontmatter, and backmatter. Although maps and bookmaps share a similar structure, bookmaps contain a more expansive set of elements, which provide many more options for preparing your content for publication—particularly if you have large amounts of it. This makes bookmaps better suited to publishing content in book format, and more flexible than maps overall.

When you’re deciding whether to compile your topics into a map or a bookmap, your publication and delivery process should be a major factor. If you need to deliver your content in print or PDF form, it is generally recommended that you use bookmaps instead of maps. Maps are sufficient for online distribution, but bookmaps are better if you plan to publish in both print and electronic formats.

One of the main differences between bookmaps and maps is the ability to have chapters in a bookmap. In a map, you can nest second-level topics under a first-level topic to create a hierarchy. In a bookmap, you these first-level topics are designated as container topics for chapters. Although the hierarchical structure of topics is the same, there is added semantic value in calling the first-level topics chapters. When you publish the same set of topics in a bookmap instead of a map, your output transforms can apply different styling based on the presence of chapters.

Bookmaps also give you much more flexible options for defining metadata than maps. You can add metadata to the bookmap, to the frontmatter and backmatter, and to each chapter, topic reference, or map reference in the bookmap. There are more metadata elements available for bookmaps than there are for maps, and many of these elements are better suited to publishing book-like structures.
